text: Julio E. Rubio (full name: Julio Ernesto Rubio Barrios) is a Mexican researcher and administrator at Tecnológico de Monterrey. ==Academic recognition== Rubio is a Level I member of Mexico's National System of Researchers (SNI). In 2009, Rubio was accepted as a member of the National Thematic Research Network on Science, Complexity and Society, Mexico. ==Education== Rubio received his PhD from the University of Valencia, Spain in 1999. He graduated cum laude, the highest distinction in Spain, for this dissertation The Construction of Scientific Knowledge: The Case for the Concept of Genetic Information (La construcción del conocimiento científico: el caso del concepto de información genética). In this work, Rubio argues that scientific knowledge is generated by communication systems that are distinguished by codes of formalization and interpretation of reality.Cibernetia. (n.d.) Thesis doctorales: filosofía de la biología [Doctoral dissertations: philosophy of biology]. Rubio earned an MA in Philosophy of Science from the Metropolitan Autonomous University (UAM), Mexico. His thesis subject was Reductionism and Emergentism in the Hypercycle Theory (Reduccionismo y emergentismo en la teoría del hiperciclo). Rubio has also earned MS in Physics from the University of Texas at El Paso. Finally, Rubio earned with honorable mentions an Electronics and Communications Engineering Degree from the Tecnológico de Monterrey. ==Research interests and contributions== As a researcher, Rubio's fields of interest include epistemology of natural science, systems theory, and sociology of technology, generally focusing on the topics of scientific and technological innovation. He has written numerous works on these topics, including articles in both peer-reviewed and public interest journals. He has edited a book on these subjects, and is working on two more.Office of Research and Graduate Studies. (2011). Julio E. Rubio . Investigación y Posgrado, Tecnológico de Monterrey, campus Ciudad de México. He also wrote the prologue of the book Science, Technology and History (Ciencia, tecnología e historia) by the scholar Javier Ordoñez.Libros: Recensiones de los libros [Book reviews]. (2004). Revista de Educación, (334), 417-473. Rubio has also applied the triple helix approach to the subject of patents. According to Rubio, the lack of nationally developed patents in Mexico is a sign of weakness and technological dependence. In order to increase the number and quality of patents developed in Mexico, Mexico must focus on building a stable knowledge society. In order to do so, it is important for Mexico to develop a national innovation system, in which business, academia and government work in concert. In particular, universities must own their role as producers of knowledge.Lydiette Carrión. (11 October 2010). El problema de las patentes: una hidra de tres cabezas . Educación a Debate. Government also needs to increase incentives for patent production. For instance, the SNI should take patent development into account in evaluation a researcher's academic contributions.Brenda Diaz. (22 November 2010). Las instituciones de educación superior dan primeros pasos en proceso de patentado. La Reforma. Seed funding is also essential, as patents lead to the development of new businesses, which in turn further the innovation process.Brenda Diaz. (21 November 2010). Protegen muy poco lo que investigan. La Reforma. Retrieved from: Factiva. Rubio has argued that the lack of cooperation between government, academia and industry is not specific to patents production, but rather of the overall state of affairs in Mexico.Luis Rodríguez Yunta. (2010). Ciencia y documentación en español en el espacio virtual iberoamericano: rol de las revistas científicas y desarrollo de nuevos productos electrónicos de información bibliográfica (Doctoral dissertation, Universidad Complutense de Madrid, 2010). According to Rubio, a dynamic economy is built on stable structures, without which optimal employment levels are impossible. As such, in Mexico, there is the paradoxical state of affairs that in Mexico these is a lack of human capital, even though trained professional are available in increasing numbers.Sonia del Valle. (8 August 2003). Urgen a ajustar sistema educativo y económico: Llaman a reactivar la economía . El Norte. He was previously Dean of Academics of the Rectoría de la Zona Metropolitana de la Ciudad de México (RZMCM) of Tecnológico de Monterrey and Dean of Research of the RZMCM.ASTM International. (June/July 2010). ASTM Standardization News.Presentan al nuevo director de investigación de la RZMCM . (2011). Talento Tec. He has also served as head of Tecnológico de Monterrey's Mexico City and Santa Fe campuses.Concluye el Campus Santa Fe otro semestre de actividades. (12 June 2005). La Reforma. Retrieved from the Factiva database. Rubio has also served on the board of directors of the Mexican Council of Graduate Studies (COMEPO).Mariana Sánchez Saldana. (November 2007). Modelo integral de evaluación del posgrado nacional . More than 60 Mexican research universities are current COMEPO members, including the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM), the Metropolitan Autonomous University (UAM) and the National Polytechnic Institute (IPN).COMEPO.
